user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_irq_ack(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 int irq)
{
	(void)lbus;
	(void)irq;
	int irq_info = 1;
	unsigned int val;
	int ret;

	ret = read(ldev->fd, (void *)&val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
		return;
	}
	ret = write(ldev->fd, &irq_info, sizeof(irq_info));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",							__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",							__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
explanation: No other code fragments in the provided function call any of the standard <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.), so they do not fall under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The read() and write() calls use the address of local objects with sizes passed as sizeof(the_object) (sizeof(val), sizeof(irq_info)), so there is no use of string.h functions and no apparent buffer-size mismatch in those calls. The (void)lbus and (void)irq casts and the local variable declarations do not involve string handling. The only fragments that could hide string-handling behavior are the log macro and its invocation (because they refer to metal_fmt and the log handler implementation, which are not provided), so those are listed for investigation. No other fragments need to be investigated for Rule 21.17 based on the supplied code.
